Nestar has requested a loan of $600 to buy more clothes, especially ladies' wear. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her disposable income and hence, meet her expenses. In the future Nestar plans to open a fashion boutique shop.

loans.use: to buy more clothing, especially ladies' wear

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DANAYA ont en moyenne  34 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KANCENE/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales et des produits alimentaires.  Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DANAYA sont à leur  5ème  prêt solidaire. FOUNE 2ème  femme debout de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 310Kg de graine d’arachide. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya Group have an average age of 34 years old and five children at home. They all live in traditional extended families in Kancene/Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women are relatives and neighbours who work together buying and selling grains and food products. After successfully repaying their previous loans, the women of the Danaya Group are on their fifth group loan. 

Foune is the woman standing second from the left in the photo. She intends to use this loan to buy 310kg of peanut seeds. She buys her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages, making her sales to a diverse clientele of women and men in cash and often on credit. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, which she will use for expenses related to health, food, clothing, and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  BENKADI est constitué de  4 femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles nucléaires dans le quartier  MASSABLACOURA de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 4 ème prêt. Les 3 précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait les activités de    restauration à l’image de BAYO qui est la 1ère femme assise  dans la photo de la droite vers la gauche . Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 200 kg de riz, 50 kg de poissons frais et beaucoup de condiments avec les grossistes  de Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle mixte . 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of 4 married women with an average age of 32 and, on average, 3 children. They live in nuclear families in the district of Massablacoura in Bougouni town. They got to know each other via neighbourly and business relationships and friendships. They joined the MFI Soro Yiriwaso in order to strengthen their financial capacity so that they can better do business and are on their 4th loan. The 3 previous loans have been correctly repaid.

Bayo, the group representative (who is sitting on the far right in the picture), runs a restaurant. She plans to use her loan to buy 200 kilos of rice, 50 kilos of fresh fish and a lot of condiments from the wholesalers in Bougouni. She makes her sales at the market and at home, for cash or credit, to a varied retail clientèle. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 30 000 francs, part of which will be reinvested in her business and part of which will be used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna lives in Tsater villager in Lori region. She lives alone as her only son have to leave to go abroad for work. Anna runs a farm. She breeds cattle and cultivates land. The gathered agricultural products (milk, meat, cheese) Anna sells to local wholesalers and gathers income for her living. 
Anna has now applied for this loan of USD 2000 to be able to enlarge her farm. She plans to purchase 2 calves, 4 piglets, forage for the livestock and potato seeds for cultivation. She hopes that lenders will support her farm and help her to enlarge it further. 
This is Anna's second loan. She has taken a loan from local financial institutions before, but because of very difficult financial conditions, wasn't able to pay it back on time. Now, by ensuring that her agribusiness is successful and she is able to provide monthly payments for this loan, Anna has been approved for this loan. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products.

loans.use: to pay for 2 calves, 4 piglets, forage for the livestock and potato seeds for cultivation

loans.name: Ruyanja Group

texts.en:
Peninah lives in Hoima Uganda.She is thirty four years old.She has a restaurant  and eans side income from brick laying.She started business so as to maintain the family.She is a single mother of four children.
She desires to educate her children.
Competition hinders her business.
She is acquiring a loan to improve her restaurant and buy rice,matooke,beans and other ingredients used for preparing food.

loans.use: mprove her restaurant and buy rice,matooke,beans and other ingredients used for preparing food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her children's education.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 30-year-old Bridget from Masvingo. She is a single parent with one child who attends school.  Bridget runs a retail business selling cosmetics and cell phones. The business has been in operation for two years. She says her main challenge is pilferage by other workmates. Bridget has requested a loan of $400 to buy cosmetics for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her an increase in disposable income. In the future Bridget plans to open a big shop.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJEKAFO ont en moyenne  44 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KANCENE/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales, des produits alimentaires et des condiments.  Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJEKAFO sont à leur  5ème  prêt solidaire. YABA 1ère femme debout de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 80Kg de graine d’arachide. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djekafo Group have an average age of 44 years old and six children at home. They all live in traditional extended families in Kancene/Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women are relatives and neighbours who work together buying and selling grains, food products and condiments. After successfully repaying their previous loans, the women of the Djekafo Group are on their fifth group loan.

Yaba is the woman standing on the right in the photo. She intends to use this loan to buy 80kg of peanut seeds. She buys her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages, making her sales to a diverse clientele of women and men in cash and often on credit. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000FCFA, which she will use for health expenses and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts

loans.name: Phamela

texts.en: Phamela is a farmer from Trinidad, Bohol. She is a mother of a 3-year-old child. Phamela primarily grows rice crops to sell. She requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. Phamela hopes to increase her harvest, thus augmenting her yield and income. In the future, Phamela has hopes of making her business a success.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe SABOUGNOUMA ont en moyenne  30 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KANCENE/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales et d’arachide.  Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe SABOUGNOUMA sont à leur  4ème  prêt solidaire. MAH 2ème femme  de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 160Kgs de graine d’arachide. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 60 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Sabougnouma group have an average age of 30 and, on average, 3 children and all live in traditional extended families in Kancene/Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women got to know each other via family and neighbourly relationships and buy and sell cereals and groundnuts. Having properly repaid their previous loans, the women of the Sabougnouma group are on their 4th group loan.

Mah (standing second from the left in the picture) plans to use her loan to buy 160 kilos of groundnuts. She gets her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages. She makes her sales for cash and often credit to a clientèle composed of women and men. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 60 000 francs, part of which will be spent on healthcare, food and educational expenses and the rest of which will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts.

loans.name: Jabulani

texts.en: Greetings from Zimbabwe, this is Jabulani in Bulawayo, the second largest city in the country. Jabulani is 38 years old, and married with five children, three of whom are attending school. For the past five years Jabulani has been running a retail shop selling cellphones and cellphone accessories. His main challenge is lack of funding to fully stock his shop, to meet the demands for his products. He has requested a $750.00 loan to buy cellphones and cellphone accessories for resale. Jabulani says the profits from the loan will enable him to open new outlets in town and improve the welfare of his family. He plans to open a couple of outlets in the near future.

loans.use: to buy original cellphones and cellphone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase men's, women's, and children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJEKAFO ont en moyenne  37 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KANCENE/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des céréales et d’arachide. Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJEKAFO sont à leur  5ème  prêt solidaire. SAFIATOU 2ème  femme debout de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 250Kg de graine d’arachide. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djekafo Group have an average age of 37 years old and six children at home. They all live in traditional extended families in Kancene/Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women are relatives and neighbours who work together buying and selling grains and food products. After successfully repaying their previous loans, the women of the Djekafo Group are on their fifth group loan.

Safiatou is the woman standing second from the left in the photo. She intends to use this loan to buy 250kg of peanut seeds. She buys her supplies locally and in the surrounding villages, making her sales to a diverse clientele of women and men in cash and often on credit. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, which she will use for school fees. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his college tuition.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a 22-year-old single man, who has been working as a barber since ten years ago.  He was only 12-years-old when he started working to support his parents in their living.

Khaled is a hard worker, who puts so much effort in developing his business and replying to his customers' needs and requests.

Khaled is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to increase his business merchandise with newly released hair care and facial products necessary for his business development.

He might also use part of the loan to continue building his dream home and continue to develop his socioeconomic situation.  Khaled will work hard to change his shop's decorations so that it attracts current and future customers.

loans.use: To increase his business merchandise with newly released hair care and facial products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase the number of his sheep to sell and  increase his income.

loans.name: Al- Ahd Al- Jadid Group

texts.en:
Al- Ahd Al- Jadid is a group consisting of four women from Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 180,000 YER from AMB.

Iman is the leader of the group. She is a 29-year-old, single woman, living with her family in one house. She is a university graduate, and now she is an employee in the private sector.  She uses her salary to cover the family’s expenses. Her father works as an officer in the army. Unfortunately, they live in very old house. The father wants to renovate the house. The renovation of the house costs a lot of money and his salary is not enough. For this reason, Iman applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to renovate the house and purchase building materials such as bricks, cement, windows, and doors. 
Iman looks forward to building more apartments and renting them in order to provide her family with a better future.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and to renovate the house.

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME ont en moyenne  46ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à KANCENE/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de céréales et les activités de restauration.  Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME sont à leur  4ème  prêt solidaire. FATOU 1ère femme  de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 10Kg de riz, 5Kg de viande 2Kg d’oignon, 2 Litres d’huile et un demi paquet de Cube Maggi. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme Group have an average age of 46 years old and six children at home. They all live in traditional extended families in Kancene/Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women are relatives and neighbours who work together buying and selling grains and food services. After successfully repaying their previous loans, the women of the Djiguisseme Group are on their fourth group loan.

Fatou is the woman standing at the left in the photo. She intends to use this loan to buy 10kg of rice, 5kg of meat, 2kg of onions, 2 liters of oil and half a package of Maggi cubes. She buys her supplies locally and makes her sales to a diverse clientele of women and men in cash and often on credit. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000FCFA, which she will use for expenses related to health and school fees. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for her food-serving business

loans.name: Hanadi

texts.en:
Hanadi is a 43-year-old married mother of five children, who has been working since four years ago at her house selling clothes, underwear and special blankets and bed shields.  This helps to support her beloved husband in their living and in covering their children's increasing needs.
Hanadi is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with a special newly released spring/summer collection to attract new customers, and to fulfill her current clients' needs.
She is very anxious about this loan because she believes that she is capable of providing her customers with the best products and prices they might request. She is also very sure that she is capable of selling everything and expanding her working sector since she is well known with her special customer care and quality of products provided.
She hopes that in the future, she might open her own diversified clothes and home need products shop and attract more customers.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with special new released spring/summer collection

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en:
Gayane lives in Mghart village with her husband and two daughters. She is a teacher with 10 years of experience teaching at local school. Gayane and her husband are also running a farm. They keep a livestock and cultivate wheat, barley and potato. The whole family works hard to gather good harvest and sell it locally. Now, they have some financial difficulties and are not able to farming costs.
 Therefore Gayane asks this loan of USD 2500 to be able to purchase seeds, fertilizer and fuel for organizing land cultivation. She will be very thankful if lenders support her farm and help her to gather more income. 
As this is Gayane's first loan,  it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products in the past because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for seeds, fertilizer and fuel for organizing land cultivation

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben is a 32 year old married and hardworking Ugandan man living in Kagadi,Uganda with 8 children aged between 10 and 1 years and 4 attend school. He has been selling textile clothes, farming and doing motorcycle transport because there was no such a business in the locality. He hopes to complete his residential house even with effects of low capital. Ben intends to use a loan to buy clothes for resale.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kiguhyo Tweimukye Group

texts.en: Joseph is a Ugandan married man, aged 80 years with 6 children aged between 40 and 27 years. He lives in Kagadi where he has been operating a retail shop, rearing cattle and goats and selling produce. He hopes to educate his grand children and grow his business despite price fluctuations and seasonal changes. Joseph is requesting for a loan to buy maize for resale. He is a member of Kiguhyo Tweimukye Group where each member guarantees the other to get a loan since they don’t pledge securities.

loans.use: to buy maize for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his children's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: A loan of 2,500 helps Haidar to pay for his daughter's education.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his son's education, uniform and books.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her daughter's education.

loans.name: Pasquelina

texts.en:
Pasquelina is 40 years old from Olkalou. She is married to Charles and they are blessed with two children aged eight and six years. She is a charcoal vendor, a business she has been running for the last four years. To enable her buy more stocks of charcoals to sell to her customers, she has applied for her third loan of KES 54,000 from VisionFund Kenya.

She plans to use the anticipated profits from her expanded business to engage in poultry farming, expand the current business, and to pay her loan to VisionFund Kenya. She hopes to be a successful business lady in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of charcoal to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem is a farmer from the Santuk district of Kampong Thom province. She is 51-years-old, married and a loving mother of five children, three of whom are still under her care while the others are married and live independently. To meet the daily needs of her family, Hem grows rice as the main source of income and raises some birds at home to supplement her income. She has been involved in agriculture for almost 15 years now.

The loan she's requesting from Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is to buy wood for home improvements. This loan will enable her to accommodate her children with a suitable home and protect them from the weather conditions.  In the future, she hopes to continue with her farming business to provide economic stability for her family, and especially provide a good education for her children.

loans.use: to buy wood for home improvements

loans.name: Ayitcheme 3 Group

texts.fr: Le groupement AYITCHEME 3 est composé de quatorze personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupement, nommée Ayébahi (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 55 ans a très peu fréquenté l'école. Ayébahi est mariée à un certain Soglo. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Ayébahi vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la famille sont assumées par le couple. Pour cette raison, Ayébahi vend de la bouillie à base de maïs et des gâteaux dans sa région depuis dix ans ce qui lui permet de répondre aux besoins de sa famille et à ses propres besoins. De façon secondaire, Ayébahi vend aussi divers produits. Ayébahi s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but d’accroître le niveau de son activité Ayébahi ensemble avec les membres du groupement AYITCHEME 3 sollicitent pour la deuxième fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le prêt antérieur a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The Ayitcheme 3 Group is composed of fourteen people who live in the same neighborhood. Ayébahi, who has her hand raised in the photo, is the representative of the group. She is 55 years old and has very little schooling. She lives with her husband, a Soglo, and together they have three children as dependents, all of whom are in school.

Ayébahi and her husband are responsible for the family's expenses. To help meet her family's needs, Ayébahi has been selling corn-based porridge and cakes in the region for ten years. As a second business, Ayébahi also sells various products. She buys her supplies at the markets in Benin. In order to grow her businesses, Ayébahi - together with other members of the Ayitcheme 3 Group - have requested a loan from ALIDé for the second time. The previous loan was successfully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase bags of corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his college tuition fees.

loans.name: Jaena

texts.en: Jaena is 51 years old, and a mother of four. She and her husband aspire to become successful and financially stable, to give their children a bright future. She engages in buying and reselling spare parts and accessories for motorcycles and hand tractors, within the local community. She aims to acquire additional stocks of those products, but she has limited capital. For this reason, she is seeking a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy additional stocks of motorcycle and hand tractors parts and accessories to sell. Through hard work and strong determination, she believes that she will be able to make her business more profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of motorcycle and hand tractor parts and accessories to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace used the previous loan to buy a generator and fridge for her business. Being an innovative woman,she has decided to open up a salon to supplement her retail business. Her business is located on a busy street where the general public can access her.Grace started the business so as to earn income. Grace has got a dream of educating her children to university level. However she is challenged with competition and shortage of customers. Grace intends to use the loan to  buy salon items like hair braids and a drier.

loans.use: to buy a saloon items like hair  braids and drier

loans.name: Milton's Group

texts.en:
Milton is a member of this group in Lugari District. He is pictured here in a group of six One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represent a total of 62 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Milton has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left.							

Milton is married and has four children.  He is fifty-five years old and is known as a friendly and hardworking experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group and burial committee.  Milton has been a farmer for nineteen years.  Milton described his harvest as good last year but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  			

The 2014 Long Rains season won’t be Milton’s first season with One Acre Fund.  He first joined One Acre Fund in 2013 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices and learn new farming methods to earn enough to feed his family and send his children to school.  As an active member in his community, Milton also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he likes being a leader and is an active community member who wants to help more farmers by spreading the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  Milton plans on using his future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and save for the future.  His life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because he has more profits from the harvest.					

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Milton and his group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

loans.use: access hybrid seeds and fertilizer for harvesting maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en:
Touch, fifty-five, is married with two children residing in a rural village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. To support the family, she has been farming rice for thirty-three years while her husband works to gain more income to better support the family. Together, they can earn about KHR 46,000 per day and can save about KHR 13,000 each day for future needs. 

Touch has been with VisionFund for three cycles and successfully used the loans to better support her family. She and her group members are applying for a loan. Touch will use her portion to pay for labor fees in ploughing the field. She hopes to harvest more rice to increase her family’s income and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to pay for labor fees in ploughing the field

loans.name: Ler's Group

texts.en:
Ler is 55-years-old and widowed. She lives with her family in a rural area located in the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province. She has two children. To support her family, she has been farming rice and raising pigs for 31 years. The current business earns her about 16,000 KHR per day to feed her family. 

This is the first micro loan for Ler with VisionFund. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Ler is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and plow the field. She hopes to increase her current business to earn a larger income to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and plow the field

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: William Marino

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito El Oro De Montecristi que se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.
En este lugar vive don Willian, tiene 45 años de edad, está casado y de esta relación tienen dos hijos de 13 y 7 años qué estudian en colegio y escuela. Su esposa es contadora.
El señor William es un hombre que siempre le ha gustado trabajar para sacar adelante a su familia, tiene un restaurante y parrillada en el centro de la ciudad, el alquila un local en el cual de jueves a domingos prepara y vende deliciosos platos, con el trabajan tres personas que son de su familia pero les paga por su servicio con lo cual ellos también pueden llevar el pan a su mesa, lleva ya casi dos años con este negocio el cual le permite salir adelante y darles un buen porvenir a su familia.
Este crédito es para comprar carne, sodas, jugos y otros víveres para preparar los alimentos. Esta desde el primer ciclo en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le permiten financiar su negocio. Sus sueños son tener un local propio ya que el pago de arriendos se le lleva gran parte de sus ganancias.
texts.en:
The "Oro de Montecristi" loan group meets every fortnight in the Montecristi canton, an area known for its rich, pre-colonial culture and for its handicrafts that are known both nationally and internationally. It is from here that the famous Panamá hat comes.

And it is here that 45-year-old Willian lives. Willian is married and has two children - aged thirteen and seven years old each - who attend school. Willian's wife is an accountant.

Willian has always liked to work in order to help his family to prosper. He has a restaurant and grill in the city centre. Willian rents premises where, from Thursday to Sunday, he prepares and sells delicious meals. He works with three family members, but pays them for their work so that they too can take home their daily bread. Willian has had this business for almost two years, and it has allowed him to get ahead and to offer his family a good future.

This loan will be used to buy meat, fizzy drinks, juices and other supplies to prepare meals. Willian has been with the loan group since the beginning and he likes it because the loans allow him to finance his business. Willian's dreams are to have his own premises as rent costs Willian a large chunk of his profits.

loans.use: to buy meat, fizzy drinks, juices and supplies.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en: Edgar is 43 and a responsible father who aims to educate his six children. He is raising his family in a rural community who makes their living through farming. Due to the high cost of school fees, he also runs a small retail store to have an additional source of income. He aims to make his business profitable, but he has inadequate capital.  For this reason, he is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy more stock of groceries, coconut pie and soft drinks to sell. Through this loan, he believes that someday he will further improve his business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of groceries, coconut pie and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to help him and his brother improve their mini-market and buy necessary products.

loans.name: Om Ahed Group

texts.en:
Om Ahed is a group  that consists of four women from Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 190,000 YER from AMB.
Thikra is a 34 year-old married woman and a mother of three children.  They are living in a miserable condition. She studied up to the secondary school, but she couldn't complete her study.  In order to improve the condition of her family, Thikra started selling incense and perfumes in her area. She has had her business for many years. She earns a good profit but it is not enough to expand her business, and most of what she earns goes to her family expenses.  Therefore, she applied for a loan of 40,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase materials to make incense. She is an expert in making Yemeni incense, but she doesn't have enough money to improve her business.
Thikra looks forward to opening a savings account in the bank. Her dreams are to become a wholesale dealer.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make incense

loans.name: Mable's Group

texts.en:
Mable is a member of this group in Lugari District.  She is pictured here in a group of seven One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of seventy-two individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Mable has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with her hand raised.  She and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving a quarter acre of maize and a quarter acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.	

Mable is married and has seven children.  She is fifty-seven years old and is known as friendly and trustworthy.  She is active in her community in groups such as the women's group and savings group.  Mable has been a farmer for thirty-four years.  Mable described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. 

Mable first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2013 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Mable joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices and earn enough to feed her family and send her children to school.  She also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she is an active community member.  Mable plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and repair the home.  She notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  Mable’s own life was improved because she has more profits from harvest, has more farm training and was able to feed the family.  				

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Mable and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.		

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: access cost-efficient hybrid seeds for maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George thanks Kiva lenders for supporting his previous loan. He used the loan to buy manure and this increased his coffee productivity in just a short time, which enabled him to make a profit.

George manages to provide his family with the basic necessities of life such as school fees and constructing a permanent house. He does this using the incomes generated by his businesses in pig cultivation and farming. He is applying for another loan of UGX 2,000,000 to buy more pigs and pig feed.

His major challenge is inadequate income to support his family, especially in paying for school fees for six of his children. His dream is to see all his children graduate from university. George is honest and hard working.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and pig feed

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
This is Emelyn, 31, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Kamal, a driver, and a father to her children. She, together with her husband, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
  
Emelyn operates an accessories retail business. What she basically does is buy accessory items from a wholesaler and then sells them per piece/pack with a profit. Customers are attracted to buy from her due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are students and mall patrons.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy different accessories like pony tails, clips and other products needed for her business.

Emelyn hopes to expand her business and dreams of giving her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for different accessories like pony tails, clips and other products.

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine is a member of this group in Lugari District.  She is pictured here in a group of 9 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 89 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Christine has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with her hand raised.  She and the other farmers represented in this group each receive ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer receives an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.							

Christine is 60 years old and has been a farmer for 40 years.  Christine provides for her 6 children.  The community and other farmers know Christine as friendly, hardworking, and experienced.  She is involved in her community's  women's group, prayer group, and burial committee.  Christine described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.							

The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Christine’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2012 and has continue working with One Acre Fund to get the best seed prices, learn new farming methods, and get fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  As an active member in her community, Christine also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she likes being a leader, and wants to help more farmers.  Christine plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school, save for the future, and buy a cow.  Her life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because she has more profits from harvest, training, and group support.  She was able to save money, and feed the family.							

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Christine and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund provides training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to gain access to cost efficient maize, millet, and sorghum hybrid seeds.

loans.name: Githagara Women Group

texts.en:
Mary, Hellen and Selina are leaders of Githagara Women Group, which is based in Kiambu. They have been with VEP for the last four years. They are dairy farmers who provide income to support their families. They borrowed the first loan to buy cook stoves to distribute to their village.This idea worked out well for them as they were able to make a profit of around $2000 with 70 stoves. With the profit, they paid back the loan and expanded their business stall. They have approached VEP for a second loan that will help them purchase more cook stoves and solar lanterns to stock their stall.
This will help them create more awareness of energy-saving Jikos that are cost effective and environment friendly. They also hope to target families using kerosene to upgrade them to solar lamps that will help their children study longer

loans.use: To purchase cook stoves and solar lanterns for sale

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth is a single woman who has two children of her own. She also cares for her late sister's child. She lives in Mangu, Kiambu County, in central Kenya. She belongs to the Kwarahuka Women group, which is with VEP. She is also a business lady, selling fuels including wood, saw dust, and charcoal.

Beth borrowed her first loan to purchase cook stoves to sell, thereby boosting her income. From the fuel business she earns at least $2.25 per day. From sales of cook stoves that she bought with the loan capital, she earned an additional $3.40 per day. With this added income, she was able to repay the loan and support her family.

Her next objective is to grow her business and create employment for others. She has approached VEP for another loan. She will use it to obtain more "jikos" (cook stoves), as she has expanded her business and network. Demand for "jikos" has increased in her region, and as a result, she needs more stock.

Beth repaid her previous loan without default, demonstrating that she is a reliable person.

loans.use: To purchase more cook stoves to resell

loans.name: Srikandi 1 Group

texts.en:
Ni Made and all the members of Srikandi 1 Group successfully repaid their loans on time. The repayment was carried out by the head of the group because most of the members were attending a ceremony at the temple. Ni Made sold all of her pigs and earned a satisfactory profit. She’s very happy with this result because now she can buy more superior piglets and renovate her house. She used the profit to buy paint to painting her house. 

Because the price of pig feed is high, the Srikandi 1 Group has requested a larger loan than before. Each member will get 3.500.000 IDR. The loan will be used to buy high quality piglets and feed.

Ni Made used her previous loan to buy two superior piglets and quality feed. To reduce costs, she still gives a mixed feed to the piglets. She hopes the pigs will grow healthy and not be attacked by diseases. If she already have enough savings in the future, she will raise pigs with her own capital.

loans.use: to buy two piglets and good quality feed

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en:
Chhim is 69 years old and lives in a common-law marriage with her husband. They live in Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province where they work in agriculture. She grows rice as her major source of income. After 39 years growing rice, she has earned well and has gradually improved her business. Her products are harvested and sold in her local community.

Chhim dreams of improving her general living conditions and providing her children with higher level of education.  She asks for a loan to buy ingredients to make steamed buns to sell in her community. She expects this will boost her earnings and profits and  achieve her dreams.

 She is very grateful to all kind lenders.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making steamed buns to sell in her community.

loans.name: Mut

texts.en:
Mut is a farmer in Prey Kabbas district, Takeo province. She was photographed with her husband, at home. Together, they have given birth to five children, two of whom are employed in their respective careers. The remaining children are dependent upon her.

Mut began farming in 1980, with a hope of earning enough profit from the business to provide for the needs of her family. She is a very hard-working woman. She works five to seven hours per day at the rice field, and she uses the rest of her time to take care of her family.

Mut will use this loan to build a hygienic latrine and septic tank for the use of her family members. In this way, she will improve her household's sanitation practices. Thanks to the water loan program, with an attractive interest rate offered by Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL), Mut is encouraged to focus on ensuring healthy living conditions, safeguarding her family's health and protecting their environment.

loans.use: to build a hygienic latrine and septic tank for her family

loans.name: Khom's Group

texts.en:
Khom is a 50-year-old single woman. 

To make a living, she grows rice and works for others for a fee. She earns about 26,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s need.

Khom has been with VisionFund for three cycles and repaid the loan. She leads her group in asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield and make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Nancy Esperanza

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito El Oro De Montecristi que se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.
En este lugar vive la señora Nancy, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos mayores de edad, los dos menores  aun viven en su casa. Su esposo es taxista.
Doña Nancy es un ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos y con esto ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa americana y productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Ella sale a vender casi todos los días unas  dos o tres horas por día ya sea en las mañanas o tardes ya que no tiene un horario establecido,  también vende en su casa si algún cliente así lo quiere, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada ocho días. Tiene más de 10 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual ayuda a su marido a salir adelante
Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y ropa americana. Esta desde el primer ciclo en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por los beneficios que recibe de la institución. Sus sueños son tener una boutique.
texts.en:
The "Oro de Montecristi" loan group meets every fortnight in the Montecristi canton, an area known for its rich, pre-colonial culture and for its handicrafts that are known both nationally and internationally. It is from here that the famous Panamá hat comes.

And it is here that 50-year-old Nancy lives. She is married and has five children - three are now adults, while two are still under 18 and live at home. Nancy's husband is a taxi driver.

Nancy is a housewife who, in order to earn her own money and support her husband with household costs, makes a living selling American clothes and Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women's accessories). Nancy goes out to sell her goods almost every day, for two to three hours per day. She does not have a fixed timetable and goes out in either the morning or the afternoon. Nancy also sells from her own home whenever customers wants this. Nancy sells on credit and collects payments every week. Nancy has been doing this work for over ten years and, with it, she helps her husband to get ahead.

This loan will be used to buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics and American clothes. Nancy has been with this loan group since the beginning and she likes it because of the benefits it gives her. Nancy's dream is to have her own boutique.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics and clothes.

loans.name: Sambor's Group

texts.en:
Sambor, 35, lives with her husband and three children in a rural village of the Moung Russey district, Cambodia. To feed the family, Sambor and her husband earn a living as farmers. They have been farming rice for several years, earning about 50,000 KHR per day to spend for the family’s needs.

Sambor is just with VisionFund for this cycle. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. 

She hopes to make more income from her rice paddy so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma, 43, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jonard, a farmer, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Norma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php 20,000 loan to help her continue with the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Norma dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes that her children will finish their studies.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed for her business.

loans.name: Rachell

texts.en: Rachell is a farmer from the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She is a married woman, and together with her husband, she has been in the farming business for more than five years now. This is the source of their income. Rachell is in need of additional capital for her business. She is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm. With this, she will be able to improve the productivity of her farm, thus augmenting her harvest and yield. In the future, Rachell hopes to make her business a success.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To acquire better storage and production containers for his wife’s wine business and acquire one more cow to increase his milk production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to set-up a permanent pig shelter and purchase a solar kit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To enable him acquire a pedal-pump for irrigating his garden during dry spells.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for goods for his grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his stock to 400 chicken to meet current demand, stock chicken feeds, and purchase a solar kit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To acquire fertiliser and hire manual farm labour to increase as he increase the size of his far from 6 to 12 acres

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 37-year-old  Palestinian man who lives in the Gaza Strip.  He is married and has four children.  

Mohammad chose  to take a loan from ACAD to improve their standard of living through  expanding his small bird breeding business.  Mohammad began his good project through working in his home. Mohammad  wants to expand his business to support his family.

His most important business challenges are  the Israeli blockade and rising prices of bird feed. 

Finally, Mohammed wants to thank ACAD and KIVA for letting him share his story.

loans.use: to purchase birds feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his farm by about 9 acres of pineapple plantation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To acquire more fertilizers and mulching materials for his farm as well as expand his pineapple garden by putting more land into use

loans.name: Ambignakola Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe AMBIGNAKOLA est composé de femmes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 41 ans, et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles dans le village de Zanfina, commune de Guégnéka, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la République du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la restauration, le commerce, de céréale, de condiment, de charbon, de couvre lit, et de savon. Les femmes du groupe AMBIGNAKOLA sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire. Dans le but de satisfaire la demande énorme de leurs clientèles, elles font recours à SORO YIRIWASO.
Ces montants seront utilisés pour acheter leurs marchandises déjà citées.
La cliente YASSA , première personne à partir de la gauche dans le rang debout est actuellement vendeuse de couvre lit d'occasion. Elle compte acheter 40 pièces de couvre lit chez les grossistes de Fana. La vente se fait à son domicile et parfois en ambulante en espèce et en crédit à une clientèle mixte. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000Fcfa, qui sera utilisé pour assurer les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
AMBIGNAKOLA is a group of married women who average 41 years of age and three children each. They live in traditional families in Zanfina, a village in the commune of Guégnéka, prefecture of Dioïla (Koulikoro region, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know one another as neighbors and friends, and through ties of kinship. They run restaurant activities and sell cereals, condiments, soap, charcoal and bed covers.  

To meet their massive customer demand, the group members joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, and this is their 9th group loan cycle. The funds will be used to stock up on merchandise to sell. 

Yassa is the group member standing first from the left in the photo. She is currently a reseller of second-hand bed covers. She plans to use her loan to buy 40 bed covers from wholesalers in Fana. She retails her stock to a diverse clientele, cash or credit, from her home or as a street vendor.  

Yassa expects to earn a monthly profit of 65,000 FCFA, which she will use to cover her family’s daily expenditures.

loans.use: to buy bed covers for resale.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a 36-year-old, married mother of two children. She has been working, selling clothes for 18 years. 

In 2013, Lina started her own business, opening her own clothes-selling shop with her special selling techniques and quality of products provided. She is well-known in her region with the special talents in her domain, in addition to the customer care she provides.

Today, Lina is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, to increase her business merchandise with a special spring/summer, newly-released collection to attract new customers and diversify her products.  

Lina is very proud of her business progress and is looking forward to opening a larger branch in the future.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with a special spring/summer, newly-released collection to attract new customers and diversify her products.

loans.name: Jessica Alexandra

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito Virgen Del Rosario  se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. En este sitio la mayoría de los habitantes se dedican a la fabricación de botones de tagua, artesanía y comercio en general.
En este lugar vive la señora Jessica, tiene 29 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 12, 10 y 7 años que estudian en colegio y escuela. El marido es comerciante. 
Doña Jessica es una mujer muy luchadora que le gusta trabajar y con sus ganancias  ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, ella tiene un pequeño comedor en su casa donde prepara en las mañanas el delicioso ceviche de pescado el cual es muy degustado por sus clientes que día a día llegan hasta su local, allí también vende jugos y gaseosas para acompañar sus platos, ella también  por las noches  vende fritadas, esto le gusta ya que le encanta cocinar y también sus ganancias que le sirven para darle una vida digna a sus hijos, ya son 7 años que lleva con este negocio y espera cada día mejorarlo más.  
Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar pescado y otros víveres para la preparación de los alimentos. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace tres años  y  le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor  a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The "Virgen del Rosario" loan group meets every fortnight in Colorado, in the Montecristi canton, an area know for its rich, pre-colonial culture and for its handicrafts that are known both nationally and internationally. Here the majority of inhabitants make a living making ivory palm buttons and artisan goods, or running businesses.

And it is here in Montecristi that 29-year-old Jessica lives. She is married and has three children - aged twelve, ten and seven years old respectively - who attend school. Jessica's husband is a businessman.

Jessica is a very plucky woman who likes to work and use her profits to help her husband with household costs. Jessica has a small restuarant in her home where she prepares "ceviche" (a marinated fish dish) in the mornings. Popular with her customers who come by every day, Jessica also sells fruit juices and fizzy drinks to serve with her meals. In the evenings, Jessica sells fried foods. She likes this work as she loves to cook and her profits allow her to give her children a decent life. Jessica has had the business for seven years and she hopes to improve it more every day.

This loan will be used to buy fish and other supplies for preparing meals. Jessica has been in the loan group for three years and likes it because she can take out loans. Jessica's dream is to give her children the best that she can.

loans.use: to buy fish and supplies.

loans.name: Deniz

texts.en:
Deniz is married and has two children.She began sewing minor repairs and took classes on tailoring.  She decided she wanted more out of life and there were more things she could do.  She put a sewing machine in a room in her house and began sewing fabric, coverlets, and bedding.  

Deniz had very few materials.  She requested a loan, which she will use to buy more types of fabric.  She wants to use her profits to provide her children with better opportunities.

loans.use: to purchase more types of fabric

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Ouch is aged 26 years and married. She resides in a rural village of the Memot district, in Kampong Cham province. She has two children, both of whom are in school. To support the family, Ouch and her husband have been in rice and cassava farming. They also do work for others, for a fee. The current business earns her family about 42,000 KHR per day, to meet her family’s needs.

Ouch has been a member of Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for one previous loan cycle. She successfully used the past loan to better support her family, by providing more food. Now she is applying for a new loan, which she will use to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to increase further her income from her farming business, so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Savan

texts.en: Savan, aged 32, lives in a rural village of the Battambang district, and she has two children. She and her husband are rice farmers, and they also work as paid workers to earn additional income for their family. Having been in this business for several years, she is able to earn about USD 17 per day to support her family.  This is the first micro loan for Savan with VisionFund. Now she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to make living better.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy trousers, blouses and sandals from Masaya, a department in Nicaragua.

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
Moustafa is a single, 21-year-old Iraqi youth client who lives with his parents and his three brothers.  He owns a small shop, selling mobile phones and their accessories. He offers mobile phones with affordable and competitive prices, and he provides all the needed mobile phone accessories for his clients. He established his business in 2011. He is gradually gaining his experience through his practice, and he is gaining a good reputation in the neighborhood. 

Moustafa is requesting a youth loan of 1,200 USD to install a rolling shutter and signage for his shop. 

He aims to grow his business and increase his revenues so that he may provide himself a good career with better living conditions.

loans.use: to install a rolling shutter and signage for his shop

loans.name: Bonne Semence (1) Group

texts.en:
Philemon is a member of the group BONNE SEMENCE (1), and is the leader of a group consisting of four other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Congo. Philemon is the father of four children between the ages of 16 and 20, two of whom are still in school. Since starting with HOPE Congo in 2010, Philemon is currently on his sixth loan cycle. 

Arriving at the market early to sell his fresh produce, Philemon wins over his customers with affordable prices and a warm welcome. After having been in the grocery business for five years, Philemon hopes to expand his business in the future from simply growing crops to also raising livestock. 

His dreams for the future are to be able to give a good education and everything he has to his family.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit and vegetables for his stand.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is married and has nine children who attend school. She is a farmer from San Miguel, Bohol, which she has been doing for several years with her husband.

Rita requested a loan, which she will use to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm. With this loan, she will be able to increase her harvest and yield from her farm. In the future, Rita hopes to make her business a successful one. She wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticides for the farm

loans.name: Josefa Del Carmen

texts.es: Doña Josefa es originaria de la ciudad de Nandaime, casada y madre de cuatro hijos dos de ellos ya independientes. Tiene 40 años de edad. Es de oficio comerciante, se dedica a la venta de fritangas (Enchiladas y Tacos). Inicio su negocio con la elaboración y venta de Tortillas y fue incrementando su clientela, luego vio la posibilidad de elaborar tacos, enchiladas  y repochetas y poco a poco ha ido aumentando sus ventas y obteniendo mejores ingresos. Su meta próxima es expandir su negocio y ofrecer una amplia variedad de comidas. Solicita el crédito para comprar: Masa de Maíz, Carne, Repollo, Tomate, Crema, Salsa de Tomate entre otros ingredientes. Estima que el crédito le será de mucha ayuda ya que podrá incrementar su inventario y así lograr mayores ventas. Su plan futuro es mantener su negocio estable.
texts.en:
Josefa was born in the city of Nandaime. She is married and the mother of 4 children, 2 of whom are already independent. She is 40 years of age and is a merchant who sells "fritangas" (enchiladas and tacos).

Josefa began her business by making and selling tortillas and it has been growing. Later, she saw the possibility of making tacos, enchiladas and other snacks. Little by little, her sales have increased and she has earned a better income. Josefa's next goal is to expand her business and offer an ample variety of meals.

Josefa is requesting this loan in order to purchase tortilla dough, meat, cabbage, tomatoes, cream, and tomato sauce among other ingredients. She believes that the loan will be a great help, allowing her to increase inventory and thus, gain more sales.

Josefa's future plan is keep her business stable.

loans.use: buy tortilla dough, meat, cabbage, tomatoes, cream, and tomato sauce among other ingredients.

loans.name: Kry's Group

texts.en:
Kry is a 33-year-old, married mother of three children. She comes from a rural village of the Tbaung Khmum district, in Kampong Cham province. Rice farming has been the main source of her family’s income for 15 years. To better support the family and earn more income, her husband also works for others, as a paid laborer. Together, they can earn about 39,000 KHR per day to meet their family’s needs. They can manage to save about 27,000 KHR each day, for their future needs.

Kry is taking her first loan from VisionFund. She is the group leader. She will use her portion of this loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to grow a healthy and fruitful rice crop. She also hopes to earn more income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Yoerm's Group

texts.en:
Yoerm, 61, is married and lives with her husband and three children in a village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. To make a living, Yoerm has been farming rice for 12 years, earning about 60,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Yoerm has been with VisionFund for seven cycles. She has successfully paid back the past loans, which have helped relieve her family’s financial burden and improve their livelihood. Now requesting another loan with VisionFund, Yoerm, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crops yields and earn more income to better her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for tuition fees and education equipment.

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita is a  married woman from San Miguel, Bohol.  She has a 13-year-old child.  She is engaged in farming.  She grows and sells rice for a living. Bernardita works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family especially for the schooling of her child.

Bernardita is asking for a loan  to buy fertilizer, a sprayer and to pay a laborer's fee.  With this, she will be able to improve her farm thus augmenting her harvest and yield. In the future,  Bernardita has hopes of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, a sprayer and to pay a laborer's fee

loans.name: Rabbi (1) Group

texts.en:
Romain is a member of the group RABBI (1) and an enterprising drink seller. He leads a group of eight other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Congo. 

Romain has just started his very first loan cycle with HOPE Congo, and plans to use his loan to expand his drink-selling business. 

Romain's strategy for success is offering his clients a low price compared to other vendors in the market. 

Supporting two children who are still in school, Romain dreams of being able to give a home and everything he has to his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional beverages to sell

loans.name: Bonne Semence (2) Group

texts.en:
Lylie is a member of the group BONNE SEMENCE (2). A mother of two children, Lylie is the proud owner of a small restaurant and drink stand. She leads a group of three other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Congo, and is now in her fourth loan cycle with HOPE Congo. 

Since starting with HOPE in 2011, Lylie wishes to increase her business by expanding to a larger premises and diversifying what she sells.

In addition to supporting her two children, Lylie also takes care of her father, and hopes to be able to provide her family a house of their own in the future.

loans.use: to expand to a larger premises and diversifying what she sells.

loans.name: Aadel

texts.en:
Aadel is a hardworking client from Iraq. He is 38 years old, married, and has a single child. He is the sole provider of his family. Aadel has a small shop where he provides his neighborhood with fresh fruits and vegetables. He has been running this business since 2008. He now has a hired employee, and is well known in his neighborhood, thanks to his fresh products.

Aadel is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD. He will use this loan to renovate his shop, and to buy more goods to sell. Aadel is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits, so that he may provide a better income for his family.

loans.use: to renovate his shop, and to buy more good to sell.

loans.name: Aisas

texts.en:
Aisas is a farmer from Chhloung, Kracheh province.  She is a 43-year-old married woman with three children who are all in school.  Aisas has been in the farming business for more than six years now.  She grows rice and cassavas on her own farmland and earns a good income for her family.  This is the sole source of her income.

This will be her first loan which will be used to buy a set of solar home systems to install on the top roof of her house, which is located in the off-grid area of the province.  After being with Hattha Kaksekar Limited, she can gain access to micro-finance services and solar energy, which she uses to power her household appliances such as light, TV and radio, so everyone in her family can even work or study at night.  She expresses her thanks to all lenders in advance.

loans.use: to buy a set of solar home systems to install on the top roof of her house.

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
A resident from a rural village of the Moung Russey district, Srey is a 20-year-old mother of five children.  The main sources of the family’s income is from rice farming and working for others for a fee.  With her current business, she can earn about KHR 35,000 per day to spend for daily expenses. 

This is Srey’s second loan with VisionFund.  Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan.  As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her farmland.  She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income so as to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her farmland

loans.name: Sorn's Group

texts.en:
Sorn is 48 years old; she is living with her husband and five children in a rural village of the Moung Russey district. Rice farming is the only main source for her family’s income, and she has been farming rice on a five-hectare area of farmland for about 12 years. The current business earns her family the daily income of about 50,000KHR to meet the family’s need.
 
This is the first loan for Sorn with VisionFund. She is now leading her group to apply for a loan. 

As the leader, she will use her portion to spend to buy fertilizer, and use a portion of it to spend on labor fees. 

She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Havva

texts.en:
Havva is married and has three children.  For a long time she has made beaded muslin and fine scarves.  She will use the loan from Maya to buy materials.  This will allow her to diversify her products and increase sales.   She is working to support her three children and ensure that they become educated.  She does everything to support her children's education.  She is a hardworking, capable and meticulous woman.

Translated from Turkish by Maya Staff 

Havva hanım, evli ve 3 çocuk annesi.  Uzun zamandır boncuklu tülbentler ,güzel fularlar yapıyor.  Maya’dan aldığı bu kredi ile malzeme alacak.  Böylece çeşidini arttırarak daha çok satış yapacak.  Üç  çocuğu ile  hayata tutunmaya çalışıyor.  Çocuklarının eğitimleri konusunda son derece destek veriyor.  Onları eğitimli bireyler olarak hayata hazırlamak konusunda çaba sarf ediyor.  Çok çalışkan, becerikli, titiz bir kadın.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Rajab

texts.en:
Rajab is 49 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has five children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Rajab has been working hard to manage his boutique, which sells men's outfits. 

To help expand his business, Rajab has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shirts, trousers, and neckties and will help Rajab to generate greater profits and increase the capital. Rajab hopes that in the future he will be able to acquire more capital. 

Rajab is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rajab, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more shirts, trousers, and neckties

loans.name: Manzura

texts.ru: Манзура 44-летняя замужняя женщина, проживает в районе Кубадиён. У нее четверо детей. Трое младших детей учатся в школе, а старший сын помогает матери в деятельности. Манзура с 2004 года занимается растениеводством. У нее богатый опыт в выращивании сельскохозяйственных культур и основной источник дохода семьи идет за счет продажи урожая. Манзура уже провела весенний посев. Для купли минеральных удобрений и топлива ей не хватило сбережения и в связи с этим обратилась за кредитом. Она очень надеется на поддержку.
texts.en: Manzura is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in the Qubadiyon District. She has four children. Her three younger children are in primary school, while her eldest son helps his mother with her business. Since 2004, Manzura has practiced crop farming. She has a wealth of experience in the cultivation of crops. The main source of income for her family comes from the sale of her harvest. Manzura has already performed the spring sowing. She does not have enough savings to buy mineral fertilizers and fuel, which is why she is requesting a loan. She really relies on your support.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers as well as tractor fuel.

loans.name: Mercedes Eulalia

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito Virgen Del Rosario se reúne cada quince días en Colorado del Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. En este sitio la mayoría de los habitantes se dedican a la fabricación de botones de tagua, artesanía y comercio en general.
En este lugar vive la señora Mercedes, tiene 48 años de edad está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos mayores de edad, uno de ellos aun viven con ella. El marido es artesano. 
Doña Mercedes es una muy buena esposa que realiza el crédito para ayudarle a su esposo, él tiene una pequeña fábrica en la cual elaboran harina de pescado, allí él y sus hijos trabajan de lunes a viernes en la elaboración de este producto, el se desplaza a Manta para comprar la parte del pescado que no utilizan las fabricas de atún, el cual el utiliza para fabricar su producto, la misma que luego de procesada la entregan a comerciantes que la exportan al extranjero donde este producto es muy utilizado. El lleva más de 16 años en esta actividad con la cual ha sacado adelante a su familia de una forma honrada.
Este crédito es para comprar pescado  para  elaborar la harina. Está  en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace muchos  años y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. Sus sueños son salir adelante.
texts.en:
The “Virgen Del Rosario” communal bank meets every fortnight in Colorado in Montecristi Canton. This place is known nationally and abroad for it's rich per-colonial culture and handicrafts. The majority of it's inhabitants make buttons from Tagua wood, make handicrafts or work in commerce.

Mercedes lives here. She is 48 years old, is married and has 3 adult children from this relationship. One of them still lives with her. Her husband is a craftsman.

Mercedes is a good wife who is making this loan to help her husband. He has a small workshop where he makes fish meal. He and his children work here from Monday to Saturday making this product. He travels to Manta to buy the fish parts that the tuna processing plants don't use, and they make their product from this. They then sell the product to businessmen who export the fish meal abroad where it is in great demand. He has been doing this for 16 years and it has allowed him to get his family ahead in a dignified way.

This loan will be used to purchase fish to make the meal. Mercedes has been a member of the communal bank for many years and is grateful for the support that the loans provide. Her dream is to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy fish.
